{{primarysources|date=March 2011}} {{Infobox_Company | company_logo = [[Image:Accel Partners logo.svg|frameless|upright=1.1|Accel Partners]]| company_name = Accel Partners | company_type = [[Private Company|Private Ownership]] | foundation = 1983 | location = [[Palo Alto, California]], [[United States|U.S.]] | industry = [[Venture capital]] | products = [[Venture capital]], [[Growth capital]]| assets = | homepage = [http://www.accel.com/ www.accel.com] | num_employees = | }}
'''Accel Partners''' is a global [[Venture capital firm|venture]] and growth [[Equity (finance)|equity]] firm. Accel funds companies from inception through the growth stage.
Accel manages over $8.8 billion from offices in [[Palo Alto, California]], [[New York City]], [[London]], [[India]] and [[China]] (through a partnership with IDG-Accel)
Over the last three decades, Accel has helped entrepreneurs build over 300 successful companies, many of which have defined their categories, including [[Facebook]], [[Groupon]], [[GetJar]], [[Cloudera]], [[AdMob]], [[Dropbox (service)|Dropbox]], [[Trivone]], [[99designs]], [[Glam Media]], [[Spotify]], [[Etsy]], [[Angry Birds]] (Rovio), [[Braintree]], Lookout, [[SunRun]], [[TRUSTe]], [[Kayak.com|Kayak]], [[Supercell (video game company)|Supercell]], [[Macromedia]], [[metroPCS]], [[Code 42 Software]], [[Flipkart]] and [[Walmart.com]].
==History==
Accel Partners was founded in 1983 by Arthur Patterson and Jim Swartz.
In 2000, Accel entered into a joint-venture with [[Kohlberg Kravis Roberts]] to form [[Accel-KKR]] a technology-focused private equity investment firm focused on control investments of middle-market companies.
In addition to Accel's continued investments in early-stage startups from the Accel X early stage fund, Accel announced its $480 million growth fund in December of 2008. This fund has focused on growth equity opportunities across a broad range of sectors, including: information technology, internet, digital media, mobile, networking, software, and services. As with Accel's early-stage efforts, Accel Growth Fund has played an active role in helping entrepreneurs and management teams build category-defining, global businesses.
In April 2009, Sukhinder Singh Cassidy, formerly [[Google]]'s President for Asia-Pacific & Latin American Operations, came on board as CEO-in-residence.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Accel Partners |title=Accel Partners Adds Google Executive Sukhinder Singh Cassidy as CEO-in-Residence |date=8 April 2009 |accessdate=2011-03-31}}</ref>
Founder of [[RealNetworks]], [[Rob Glaser]] joined Accel's Venture Development team in June 2010, focusing on digital media technology, social media, and mobile service investments.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.accel.com/news/news_one_up.php?news_id=273 |publisher=Accel Partners |title=Rob Glaser, Founder of RealNetworks, Joins Accel Partners |date=25 May 2010 |accessdate=2011-03-31}}</ref>
==Locations and People== ===Palo Alto===
Eleven partners are based in Accel’s Palo Alto office: Andrew Braccia, [[Jim Breyer]], Kevin Efrusy, Sameer Gandhi, Ping Li, Todd Maclean, Arthur Patterson, Theresia Gouw Ranzetta, Jim Swartz, Ryan Sweeney, Rich Wong.
===London===
Six partners are based in Accel’s London office: Philippe Botterri, Kevin Comolli, Sonali De Rycker, Bruce Golden, Michiel Kotting, Harry Nelis, Adam Valkin
===India===
Four partners are based in Accel’s India office: Mahendran Balachandran, Shekhar Kirani, Subrata Mitra, Prashanth Prakash.
===China===
Accel’s investments in China are operated through a partnership with IDG Capital Partners
